body:
In this module we have seen how simple it can be to analyse data once it is organised in the correct structure. 

If you haven't already, try applying what you have learnt to the course spreadsheet. 

At this point there are two possible directions. Further analysis may be required to find a story; this may require further gathering, organising and cleaning. You may even need to employ further advanced statistical techniques such as the ones outlined in the courses and exercises linked below. Alternatively, you might have discovered your story already and be ready to visualise it. The next stage is choosing the most appropriate visualisation for your data.
title: Summary

body:
Appealing to the visual cortex helps us communicate strong messages, as they can provoke a reaction even before the rest of the brain has had a chance to process the information. 

Picking the right visualisation is only the first part of telling effective stories. Plotting the right data in the correct way, making good use of colour and other visual cues is essential to making the story “pop out” at the audience.

This is essential when presenting a story to decision maker with limited time. Even with limited time, this does not guarantee engagement. There are techniques that can create intrigue, but beware that they can also mislead.
title: Summary

body:
Once your data is organised and clean, you can now begin to filter and analyse the data.

In this module we will learn how to:

  • Sort and filter data in a spreadsheet
  • Apply formula to generate simple statistics
  • Create a number of pivot tables
  • Create a number of summary graphs

To prepare you for this exercise you will need this spreadsheet. Note that it has two sheets; the first tab holds the data, and the second tab called 'Statistics' will be used when we look at formula.
title: Filtering and pivot tables

body:
Sorting and filtering data helps you to see trends in the data. 

Before applying any sort or filter operations, make sure that you have frozen the header rows.

Use the video on the right to help guide you.
title: Sorting and filtering data

_items.title: Sorting data
_items.body:
To sort a column, simply select the column header you want to sort the data by and then select the sort option, normally available from the Data menu or panel in most spreadsheet applications.

You can then choose how you want to sort the data.

_items.title: Filtering data
_items.body:
Filters allow you to limit the data that you see.

To apply a filter, select any cell in your header row and click the filter icon. This is normally available from the same place that the sort function is found.

Once selected, you will notice that your header row gains a dropdown option. Selecting or unselecting the data shown in this dropdown will allow you to both sort and filter the values in a row. This will hide the data, but not get rid of it.

body:
Spreadsheet applications have powerful formula functions to help you analyse the data. Here we are going to look at few of the simple formulas. 

This is where we will use the separate sheet in our spreadsheet for statistics. This means we will avoid including unnecessary tables in with our dataset or limiting the ability to add additional rows. All the formula used means that you can still add data to the original sheet and the statistics will automatically update in the second sheet. 

Again, you can use the video to help guide you.
title: Formula and statistics

_items.title: Averages
_items.body:
Calculating averages is a common operation with any numeric data. But remember, there is more than one type of average!

In the statistics sheet of the spreadsheet, we want to find out the mean and mode star ratings. These can be added by using the AVERAGE() and MODE() formula on the star rating column. 

To calculate the AVERAGE() star rating, type the following formula into the correct cell in the statistics sheet and then follow the instruction in italics. 

=AVERAGE( click Star Rating column in data sheet )

_items.title: Lowest and highest values
_items.body:
To find out what the lowest and highest star ratings are, you can use the MIN() and MAX() formula. 

e.g. 

=MAX( click Star Rating column in data sheet )

_items.title: Count the number of items
_items.body:
The COUNT() and COUNTA() functions help to count how many items there are in a large sheet. 

COUNT() and COUNTA() are two very similar functions. The difference between them is that COUNT() only counts cells containing numbers but COUNTA() counts all cells that aren't empty, meaning it will also count cells with text or other characters.

You can obtain the count of star rated facilities using the following formula. 

=COUNT( click Star Rating column in data sheet )

body:
A pivot table is a powerful data summary tool found in all spreadsheet tools. Among other functions, a pivot table can automatically sort, count, total or give the average of the data stored in one table or spreadsheet, displaying the results in a second table.

Pivot tables also give you the ability to "Pivot" or rotate the data, changing the column and row labels used from the original dataset. 

The example video demonstrates how to create a simple pivot table that gives the total number of health facilities per star rating. Here, the star ratings are used as the row labels and we have one column of data that represents the total count of facilities for each rating. 

Try following this through with your own dataset.
title: Pivot tables

body:
Combining all aspects of this module enables you to create a simple data analysis tool for our spreadsheet of data.

Follow the steps below to create your own data analysis interface for health care facilities:
title: Data analysis

_items.title: Advanced pivot table
_items.body:
The first stage is to create a new pivot data from our complete dataset. In this case we are going to look at the star rating of heath care facilities per region.

This time the region will be the row labels. The column headings will represent the star ratings and the values will be the total count of facilities that achieve that star rating.

In order to make filtering and analysing easier, it is recommended that only a total row for column totals be added.

_items.title: Create a graph
_items.body:
The next stage is creating a graph of the data in our pivot table. 

Simply highlight the data, including row and column titles, and click the charting tool. We want to add a clustered column chart. 

Feel free to name and style your chart to look nice. Try to not have the chart on top of the data.

_items.title: Slice your data
_items.body:
The last stage involves adding a slicer (or filter) to the pivot table. This tool can be found in the pivot table options (or toolbar). 

Add a slicer to your dataset based upon healthcare facility type. This will now allow you to filter the pivot table by type. As the pivot table updates, so will the graph that you made at the previous stage.

body:
Using a technique called 'pop out' helps direct the eye to the correct place. The dorsal stream reacts quickly to patterns and significant differences presented visually.

Pop-out works best when a combination of different visual cues are used in combination, e.g. colour, size and line thickness.

In the picture here, a combination of colour and thickness guides the eye towards the steepest line. This line represents the first high-speed train from Paris to Lyon. The steepness of the line is the speed.
title: Making information pop

body: Careful use of colour is essential and can help not only with 'pop out', but also conveying meaning.
title: Using colour
instruction: Click the forward arrow to find out how.

_items.title: Colour has meaning
_items.body:
As well as making information 'pop out', colour can also convey meaning.

For example: red, amber and green represent danger, caution, and safety. As shown in traffic lights. 

However, not all colours convey easily recognisable meaning, and too much use of colour can be confusing. In this way, try to keep the number of colours used to a minimum. 

A good demonstration of when to stop using too much colour can be found on this blog about Brexit.

_items.title: One colour
_items.body:
The human eye is much more sensitive to changes in a single colour rather than having to process multiple colours.

Grey scales (using different shades of the same colour) are useful to convey change, as the human eye has far more rods (low light receptors for grey scale) than cones (which handle different ranges of colour each).

_items.title: Picking the right colour
_items.body:
If you can't use a grey scale, then it is worth carefully considering the colours to use. Special care should be taken with colours that are too intense. 

Intense colours are those that combine colours which have long wavelengths, stimulating a lot of cones in the eye simultaneously. 

The most intense colour to the eye is yellow, as it combines the red and green receptor cones. 

As yellow can be glaring and hard on the eye, try using more neutral tones such as blue and purple, which are both used prevalently in design.

body:
Visualising data enables us to grasp difficult concepts or identify new patterns quickly.

In this module, we introduce the key tricks that help the eye and brain process and understand data much faster. 

We will cover:

  • Visualisation and the visual cortex
  • Making information pop
  • Using color
title: Visualisation best practice

body: The human brain has been specifically designed to help us instantly process and react to what we see. Understanding how the visual cortex works is essential when creating powerful visualisations of data.
title: Visualisation and the visual cortex
instruction: Click the forward arrow to find out how.
mobileInstruction: Click the forward arrow to find out how.

_items.title: The human eye
_items.body:
The human eye, along with the visual cortex, is capable of processing trillions of points of information simultaneously.

The human eye is very sensitive to detail. It can instantly re-focus on objects at different distances. It can also instantly change the amount of light that enters the eye in order to deal with high and low light levels.  

Technologies such as Light Field cameras and High Dynamic Range which have the ability to capture a level of detail similar to the eye are beginning to emerge, but have taken thousands of years longer than the eye.

_items.title: The visual cortex
_items.body:
After light has entered the eye, the information carried with it is passed to the visual cortex for processing. This information is then split by the occipital lobe to be processed in parallel by the dorsal and ventral streams. 

These two pathways have very different jobs, and understanding each is the key to effective data visualisation. 

Dorsal Stream: The where/how path
Ventral Stream: The what pathway

_items.title: Fast path visualisation
_items.body:
The dorsal stream is the pathway in the visual cortex. It is responsible for recognising where things are and how they are going to affect you.

For example, if someone throws something at you unexpectedly, it's the dorsal stream that will react to help defend you. You act without thinking.

We can use the same trick in data visualisation to make information pop without needed to rely on the ventral stream to work out what that information is first.

body:
Not starting at zero causes what is known as 'baseline failure'.

When looking at a bar chart, the human brain looks instantly at the size of the bar, not the value it represents. Therefore, to make a value difference appear larger than it is, the scale won't start at zero. 

This is a very common trick used to emphasise a difference that would appear small otherwise.
title: Baseline failure

_graphic.attribution: Fox News [All rights reserved]

body: The first thing that the brain notices when looking at a visualisation is the size of different parts.
title: Adding depth and area
instruction: Click the forward arrow to see more.
mobileInstruction: Select the + sign to explore further, then swipe the image to see more.

_items.title: Adding depth
_items.body:
Adding 3D effects increases the area of a graph. To the human brain the perceived size is now larger with the additional volume. 

Providing that the volume is equal in all cases then this is fine (e.g. the volume of an area with value 4 is exactly twice the volume of an area with value 2). 

However, if the volumes are not proportional, or as is the case here potentially infinite, then it can be difficult to grasp real values.

_items.title: Removing depth
_items.body:
Removing the 3D infinite depth shows a different view of the data. 

With the depth removed, previously large changes are no longer present in the data. 

Interestingly, this data also suffers from the fact that the figures have not been adjusted for inflation. Adjusting the figures shows that state expenditure had not changed in real terms for the previous seven years.

_items.title: Radius and area
_items.body:
Using raw values as the radius of a circle is another big mistake. 

The easy way to spot this mistake is to attempt to fit a smaller circle inside a bigger circle. For example, a circle representing the value '1' should fit in another circle representing the value '3' exactly three times. 

As can be seen in the example here, this is not the case. Smaller differences seem bigger, due to the incorrect scaling of the circles.

body: Perhaps one of the most confusing charts ever created. Introducing area, stacked area and the stream graph.
title: Area and stacked area charts

_items.title: Area charts
_items.body:
Area charts are great for showing a single value that may consist of many parts. However if being used to compare two or more sets of values they should be avoided. 

Why? 

Because when the human brain looks at an area chart it sees mountains. Which means that one set of values is behind the other. 

This is correct for an area graph, so why should you not use them? Click to the next section to find out...

_items.title: Stacked area charts
_items.body:
The stacked area chart looks exactly the same as an area chart. However the two sets of values are now on top of each other not behind one another.

How do you tell?

There is no way for sure to tell what you are looking at unless it is stated. 

Take a look at both examples here as they use exactly the same set of source data. Can you tell the difference?

_items.title: Stream graphs
_items.body:
Going one step further and introducing the stream graph.

Is this stacked or an area chart? 

Where is the zero value on the y-axis?

Is the order of items significant?

Abandon all hope!

body:
Another common method used to emphasise a difference or correlation is to use multiple scales. 

Typically, this involves having different scales on each side of the chart that each relate to different plots of data. 

The example shown here from the Colorado Department of Transport uses two scales to try and emphasise how different fatal accidents are in 2016 compared to previous years. 

Things to note:

  • The scale on the right does not start at zero (baseline failure)
  • The intervals on the two scales are different
  • The coloured bars for other years are not always for the same years (i.e. green is not always 2010)
title: Multiple scales

_graphic.attribution: Historical Fatal Car Crashes, Colorado Department of Transportation, Colorado Department of Transportation [CC-BY]

body:
As well as issues with area, pie charts can also be misleading when plotting percentages. 

A close look at this pie chart shows that the values only add up to 62%. So what happened to the other 38% of safety concerns?

It is also worth observing that the size of the 19% quadrant is also far larger than a 25% quadrant should be.
title: Percentages

body:
Visual representations of data vastly decrease the amount of time it takes to communicate a message. However, not all data visualisations are equal. In some cases, a combination of tricks are used to either emphasise a point or, in some cases, mislead the viewer. In this module we look at visual deception in data visualisation and how to avoid it.

In this module we'll explore the following: 

  • Baseline failure
  • Multiple scales
  • Adding depth and area

body:
This module explores digital maps and how open data can enhance them; how to use maps in projects; and how to visualise and explore data with them. By the end of the module, you'll have a good understanding of the issues around digital mapping, and skills that can be used in your own work.

The module explores:

  • Introduction to digital maps
  • Benefits of open mapping
  • How to describe something on a map
  • Formats and standards
  • Practical mapping with CartoDB
title: Mapping open data

body:
Ramani Huria is an excellent case study in the benefits open mapping can have. The key to the success and multiplied benefits from the project all stem from the completely open approach taken.

From the choice of mapping platform to the community engagement and crowd sourcing, the project ensured that all data remained open and that the process of collecting it was open. 

OpenStreetMap is a free, editable map of the world that is being built by volunteers largely from scratch and released with an open content license. This is a significantly different model to most mapping providers who guard their maps and charge for access and do not allow any edits. In countries such as Tanzania, OpenStreetMap allows incredibly rich maps to be created, which open up the data, so others can innovate.
title: Benefits of open mapping

body: Data visualisations can be a powerful way of bringing data to life, and helping others deduce meaning from it. But before you start visualising your data, you should consider some key aspects.
title: Appropriate visualisations for data

_items.title: Audience
_items.body:
Before creating a visualisation, you need to decide how you want to share it and who you want your audience to be.

Your audience may already have a set way of engaging with data that you cannot change. For example, if your audience is comfortable reading long reports then a visualisation may not be the best solution. 

You should also think about the medium for consumption and technology available and understandable by your audience. For example, it would not be wise to create a full-screen dashboard for those who only have access to mobile devices.

_items.title: Purpose
_items.body:
Once you know your audience, consider the purpose to your data visualisation; why are you visualising the data? 

Remember the four key reasons we introduced earlier:

  • Clear communication
  • Storytelling
  • Aiding understanding
  • Encouraging interaction with the data

Some visualisations can serve multiple purposes, however, you should try to avoid mixing clear communication with any other purpose (e.g. aiding understanding). This might dilute the message you are trying to communicate to the point where it is no longer obvious to the audience. Often this happens when the user is presented with too many visualisations or infographics together.

_items.title: Data
_items.body:
Not all data is suitable for a particular visualisation. 

For example, a line or area chart should never be used for data that is not sampled over time. 

Consider carefully your dataset type and how the data was collected. There are a number of typical types of data:

Time series: Observations of the same thing over time – best represented on a line chart or animated graphic.

Population data: Observations of different things at a single point in time – best represented by a bar chart, pie chart or other static visualisations. 

Observations: Observations of different things at different points in time – best represented on a dashboard.

Confusion can occur when a dataset combines one or more of these types of data and you must decide how to use that dataset.

body: There are many parts to a map and cartography can become an art. This section briefly looks at the many layers of a map.
displayTitle: How to describe something on a map
title: How to describe something on a map

_items.title: Points
_items.body:
Points help you precisely locate something on a map, for example, a person or a place. 

Often these are used to mark the middle of an object that might often be better represented by another map feature, such as a line or polygon.

_items.title: Lines
_items.body:
Lines represent the shape and location of geographic objects, such as street centre lines, rivers or ferry routes.

Lines are also used to represent features that have length but no area, such as contour lines and boundaries.

_items.title: Polygons
_items.body:
Polygons are complete shapes that represent a feature such as regions (as shown here) or buildings.

They can also be used to represent land-use or even soil type. 

Using GIS software, you can automatically calculate which points are in which polygon. This is often used to shade areas on a map dependant on the data collected from many points, e.g. the performance of schools in a region.

_items.title: Bringing it all together
_items.body:
Bringing all these features together allows us to create powerful maps that accurately show the layout and features of a huge area.

The example here of the centre of Dar Es Salaam is one of the most comprehensive examples in the world. This data was gathered as part of the Ramani Huria project and shows roads (lines), buildings (polygons), building use (points) and annotations that describe each point.

body:
There are a number of different data formats and standards used to represent mapping data. It is important to understand that all of the different data formats rely on one or more standard ways of representing a simple location (or point). Putting many points together enables lines and polygons to be drawn.  

Explore the different aspects below:
title: Formats and standards

_items.title: A standard way to represent a location
_items.body:
The globally recognised way to represent a location of something is via the Global Positioning System (GPS). Devices that use this system typically give location in terms of two X-Y co-ordinates on a map. 

There are however many different X-Y standards including longitude/latitude and easting/northing. 

You will have to be very careful when processing and combining mapping data to ensure that all data is using the same co-ordinates system.

_items.title: Common data formats
_items.body:
Representing simple point data (using one X-Y co-ordinate) can be done in a multitude of formats, including spreadsheets. 

However, when it comes to more complex data, such as lines and polygons, there are many other formats more suited to the purpose including KML, GeoJSON and GIS Shapefiles (as used by the National Bureau of Statistics in Tanzania). 

As with data formats, not all geographic data formats are open and easily usable by all tools. It may be necessary to use a tool such as maps data to convert between the different formats.

body:
CartoDB is a very popular online tool for creating geographic visualisations on maps. It has simple wizards to help you get started but also allows you to expose the code and customise your GIS queries to take complete control. CartoDB can also merge and boundary-locate geographic data without you having to write complex GIS queries yourself.

Several exercises have been developed to help you explore the features of CartoDB

body:
You may find something interesting when you are cleaning, analysing and interrogating your dataset. If this is significant, the next stage will be to communicate it to others. Data visualisations help to communicate insight found in data in a quick and easy way.

Creating effective visualisations is not as easy as it looks. The best examples take expertise and time to carefully create.

The transport research board in the US have produced an excellent report on data visualisation methods which explores more of the areas outlined in this module.
title: Summary: Data visualisation techniques

_graphic.attribution: Tanzania dLab [All rights reserved]
Tanzania dLab [All rights reserved]

body:
Most charts used in modern data visualisation derive from the original design of William Playfair (1759–1823), a political economist.

William Playfair invented several types of diagram: in 1786 the line, area and bar chart of economic data, and in 1801 the pie chart and circle graph. 

Playfair argued that charts communicated better than tables of data and was the early pioneer of visual communication using charts.

Read more about the history of data visualisation on wikipedia.
title: Data visualisation

body: William Playfair recognised that data tables did not effectively communicate to people. Even in the 18th century, he recognised the importance of visualising data to aid communication. Since this point, modern data literacy and access to data have meant that communication is not the only purpose of a data visualisation.
title: Why visualise data?

_items.title: Clear communication
_items.body:
Powerful messages need to be communicated clearly.

Bar charts, pie charts and clear numbers are a very effective way to communicate.

Other effective methods use large visuals and introduce figures that may help people relate to the story (e.g. stick figures could be added to represent the number of people with the visual shown here).

_items.title: Storytelling
_items.body:
A good data visualisation can also help tell an engaging story.

This piece of work by the New York Times asks readers to engage directly with the story and challenges their existing knowledge about how President Obama did during his presidency.

This can be a very effective way to entertain and directly educate users. This appears to learners who are kinesthetic and like to learn by doing. 

Why not find out how much you know about the Obama presidency?

Explore this story

_items.title: Aiding understanding
_items.body:
Many visualisations are created to aid understanding of the patterns that exist in data. 

Examples of such visualisations include scatter graphs, radar charts and bubble charts, which are often used to compare two or more aspects in data or look for early emergence of patterns in the data.

Such graphs are more complex and are not suitable for use to quickly communicate a clear message. To aid with explanation, other graphs or text will be required.

Shown is a radar graph comparing Tanzania’s open data progress to that of the rest of Sub-Saharan Africa.

_items.title: Encouraging interaction with the data
_items.body:
Some visualisations add an interactive element that allows the free exploration of data. This type of visualisation can help get people interested in the data and help them to find their own story from it. 

Dashboards are a good example of this type of visualisation. The one here shows water points in Tanzania and categorises them by how many are functional or not. 

The key to any visualisation that is intended to get people interested in open data is to link directly to the raw data, such that people can interrogate it themselves.

_graphic.attribution: Tanzania Government Open Data Portal [CC-BY]

body: The type of data visualisation you need depends on the message you are trying to communicate and the data you are working with. The following sections explore these two aspects in more detail.
title: Data visualisations and their use

_items.title: Bar charts
_items.body:
The human brain is very good at quickly judging the size of simple shapes, such as rectangles. Therefore, the bar chart can very effectively communicate differences. 

Simple bar charts can communicate powerful messages quickly. Enhancing bar charts and pie charts with graphics and well-placed text can also aid clear understanding. You do not even always need scales or lines.

A bar chart is perfect for comparing the magnitude of two or more values.

The chart on the left compares the revenue of one product to the revenue of an entire company, where the product has made more money. If you were creating a visualisation to tell this story, what might you add to make this finding stand out even more?

_items.title: Line and area charts
_items.body:
Line and area charts should only be used where there is a time series to be displayed. In most countries and cultures, people read left to right. Therefore, line charts must be constructed to be read from left to right. 

A line chart, as shown here, is best for comparing multiple sets of data over the same (or equivalent) timeframe.

An area chart can be used to emphasise the totals. When using area charts, it is best to use a stacked area to clearly show the total of all datasets over the same (or equivalent) period of time.

_items.title: Histograms
_items.body:
Histograms are used to examine the distribution of different measurements of a variable, such as the distribution of different heights in the figure here.

A histogram is perfect for showing graphically where the median and mode lie. They also show the distribution (or shape) of the data and surface any outliers that might skew the location of the mean. 

Significantly, they can reveal whether the samples in your dataset are normally distributed, or contain data that might be skewed or falsified.

_items.title: Maps
_items.body:
Many datasets are related in some way to locations, and so visualising data on a map is the perfect way to make the data come to life.

Care should be taken in creating the right type of map, and using the right features to direct the reader. This is something we look at in more detail in the next module.

The map shown here uses a simple traffic-light scale to show the teacher-to-pupil ratio in schools in Tanzania.

In the next module, we will create our own map from a similar dataset.

body:
Digital maps and the associated Geographic Information Systems (GIS) enable us to easily capture, manipulate, analyse and present spatial and geographic data. 

Geographic data here refers to any data that has an implicit or explicit association with a location. Typically, this covers a wide range of data, including positional data (e.g. locations of schools), boundary data (e.g. regions of Tanzania) and elevation data (e.g. the height of Kilimanjaro). 

Maps have for centuries been critical to helping us to understand where we are and what is around us. Digital maps go beyond this and allow us to create new data visualisations for any dataset that has a geographic connection. Digital maps can help to inform decisions that we need to make, for example...
title: Introduction to digital mapping

body:
Taking an open approach to digital mapping enables other people to help create or enrich geographic data and makes the data available for other people to benefit from. Open digital mapping platforms (e.g. OpenStreetMap) enable anyone to create their own maps using this approach. 

Ramani Huria is a community-based mapping project that began in Dar es Salaam. Its initial aim is to create highly accurate maps of the most flood-prone areas of the city and inform decisions about how to protect these areas. As the maps have taken shape, their benefits have multiplied and their potential magnified. They now serve as foundational tools for development within all socio-economic spheres in Tanzania.
displayTitle: Community mapping for flood resilience and development
title: Community mapping for flood resilience and development

body:
Data visualisations can be a powerful way of bringing data to life, and helping others deduce meaning from data.

But to add context to the visualisation, build a shareable story around it and disseminate that story widely for maximum impact, visualisations should be accompanied by a written narrative. 

This module goes through the steps you should take in putting your story into words for the best possible impact:

  • Choosing the right format
  • Planning and framing your story
  • Drafting your story
  • Polishing, publishing and promoting your story
  • Great data journalism examples
title: Narrating your story

body: Writer Anna Scott introduces why and how you should add narrative to your story.
title: Story narration in 2 minutes

body:
Stories come in many different shapes and sizes. When you want to communicate a story, you need to decide how you want to share it and who you want your audience to be.

It may be that your data story is part of a wider bit of research. In this case, you might want to write a detailed book about it. However, books are a huge time investment, and will only be read by those who are already interested in your specialist subject. To maximise your impact and reach, your story needs to be easily shareable, searchable and succinct. 

This module will focus on writing compelling online articles and blogs to share your findings, give context to your visualisations and tell your story. 

Many different businesses and organisations now invest in blogging as an agile form of communicating ideas, projects and news to the wider world. When they are well structured and engaging they can attract widespread readership and help raise the organisation's profile. On the other hand, if they are not well structured, they can put people off and even pose a risk to the organisation's reputation.
title: Choosing the right format

body:
In order to ensure your blogpost or article is well structured and engaging, it is important to take time to plan and frame your story.      

Before your begin to write, you can follow these three simple steps to make sure you have everything you need: setting out your structure, gathering your resources and drafting your headline.
title: Planning and framing your story

_items.title: Set out your structure
_items.body: Write a summary of your story with the main points that you want it to cover. It is helpful to use bullet points for this, being sure to cover the beginning, middle and end. (You might tweak these later, after having gathered your resources, but it will help to have this as a basis to draw on in the drafting stage.)

_items.title: Gather your resources
_items.body:
Once you have your draft structure set out, you can begin to gather your resources. 

You will need evidence to draw on in your story. This may come from information or quotes you find from another news story, a report, a book or an interview.

Be sure to carefully check the provenance of any sources to ensure that the data is reliable and trustworthy. Note down where the information is from and who wrote or said it. This will help with provenance checks and transparency. You should use this information to properly reference your sources when you come to drafting the piece. 

Learn more about gathering data here.

_items.title: Draft your headline
_items.body:
After having written your summary and gathered your resources you should have a good idea of what the focus of your piece will be. 

At this point it is very helpful to write a draft headline and standfirst (the two-sentence summary you see under headlines in news stories, usually in italics.) Again. this might change once you have written your piece, but it will help you to keep your main focus on mind as you write.

body:
Once you have written your summary and gathered your resources, you should be well prepared to draft your story. If you think you don't have enough resources to write what is detailed in your summary, either return to gathering resources or tweak the summary to fit with what you know. Once you have finished, read through your draft and check it for the things that will make it engaging, accessible and accurate.

This checklist will help you make sure your blog is well-structured. Ask yourself:
title: Drafting your story

_items.title: Does my draft have a clear beginning, middle and end?
_items.body:
Think of your storyline as taking the shape of an arc.

Begin simply by setting the scene - what is the main takeaway of the article?

Then build up your story. Towards the end of the article, the reader should have all the information they need.

The ending hammers home the main takeaway of the story again, bringing together the main points covered throughout the article.
_items.strapline: Does my draft have a clear beginning, middle and end?

_items.title: Does my headline fit onto two lines?
_items.body:
Five times as many people will read the headline, as will read the rest of the article.

Ask yourself, 'what will make people want to read more?', and keep it short and snappy.
_items.strapline: Does my headline fit onto two lines?

_items.title: Does my draft include URL links (or footnotes)?
_items.body:
Make sure you can substantiate your claims by pointing to the data and attributing where you can. 

Linking your publication to other websites and resources will also increase your story's exposure on the web.
_items.strapline: Does my draft include URL links (or footnotes)?

_items.title: Is there a call to action?
_items.body:
What do you want your readers do differently after reading the piece?

Whether your goal is to educate or inspire, motivate or amuse, make sure that you point towards the right resources for your readers to take action.
_items.strapline: Is there a call to action?

body: Once you're happy with your draft, take steps to getting your story out there.
title: Polish, Publish, Promote!

_items.title: 1. Polish
_items.body:
Read your draft through fully once more to make sure it is ready to launch.

Make sure all the hyperlinks are correct and link to active webpages, and be sure you have linked relevant content to the side panel if that is possible on the platform you are using to publish.

_items.title: 2. Publish
_items.body:
You should not see publishing your piece as the end of the process, but rather the beginning.

You want the blog to be read by the audience you had in mind when you wrote it, so make sure it is easy for them to find. Keeping Search Engine Optimisation (SEO) in mind when writing your headline is one of the ways in which you can make sure your piece will be visible to people who are interested in the subject of your blog.

_items.title: 3. Promote
_items.body:
Once you have published your piece, be sure to promote it using social media.

If you have quoted or mentioned specific people or organisations in your piece, link to their profiles on social media channels so they are notified and can easily share it. Asking your contacts or relevant organisations to share it across their social media channels can help you to get the widest possible reach.

displayTitle: Are you ready to communicate your story?
title: Are you ready to communicate your story?

body: Stories help us put data into the world. When put together effectively they can delight, enchant, inspire, educate, motivate and challenge us. Take a look a a number of the excellent examples here.
title: Great data journalism examples

_items.title: You Draw It: What Got Better or Worse During Obamas Presidency?
_items.body:
In this piece of work by the New York Times they ask readers to engage directly with the story and challenge their existing knowledge. 

This can be a very effective way to not only entertain but also to directly educate users. This appears to learners who are very kinetic and like to learn by doing. 

Why not find out how much you know about the Obama years?

Explore this story

_items.title: In flight: 100 years of aviation
_items.body:
To mark 100 years of passenger air travel, the Guardian created an interactive story that used live data from FlightStats. The data allowed them to show every one of the thousands of commercial planes currently in the air.

This data was one of many datasets that were combined in this inteactive story to charts the history of aviation since 1914, and ask what comes next for the industry.

Explore for yourself

_items.title: American deaths in terrorism vs. gun violence
_items.body:
In the wake of the Oct. 1 shooting at Umpqua Community College in Oregon, President Barack Obama tasked the media to put the number of gun violence-related deaths into perspective.

Obama knew that the data was available and could be analysed in many ways, all with the same stark result (if you wanted to report it).

CNN Washington Post

body:
Data increases in value the more it can be understood and shared.

In additional to a visualisation, build a shareable story around it and disseminate that story widely for maximum impact. 

So when you’ve found a  great story, make sure you tell it in a way that’s clear, relatable, and impactful.

When done effectively, telling data stories in the workplace can be a catalyst for change. Creating compelling stories is an essential skill for those who want to truly have impact.
